SENTENCE.STRING: (born Martha Craven on May 6, 1947) is an American philosopher, with a particular interest in ancient philosophy, political philosophy and ethics.
was born in New York, the daughter of George Craven, a Philadelphia lawyer, and Betty Warren, a homemaker.
studied theatre and classics at New York University (NYU) (BA 1969), gradually moving to philosophy while at Harvard (MA 1972; PhD 1975, under G. E. L. Owen).
This period also saw
marriage to Alan Nussbaum (divorced in 1987), conversion to Judaism, and the birth of
daughter Rachel.
taught philosophy and classics at Harvard in the 1970s and early 1980s, before moving to Brown University.
1985 book The Fragility of Goodness, on ancient ethics, was particularly influential, and made
a well-known figure throughout the humanities.
During the 1980s
began a collaboration with economist Amartya Sen on issues of development and ethics.
With Sen,

promoted the "capability approach" to development, which views capabilities ("substantial freedoms", such as the ability to live to old age, engage in economic transactions, or participate in political activities) as the constitutive parts of development, and poverty as capability-deprivation.
This contrasts with a common view that sees development purely in terms of economic growth, and poverty purely as income-deprivation.
It is also universalist, and therefore contrasts with relativist approaches to development.
Much of the work is presented from an Aristotelian perspective.
has used the capability approach to reinterpret John Rawls' Theory of Justice.
For
, Rawls's Liberty Principle is only meaningful if viewed in terms of substantial freedoms, i.e.
real opportunities based on personal and social circumstance.
Likewise, inequality in the Difference Principle has to be clarified in terms of capabilities.
has engaged in many spirited debates with other intellectuals, both in the pages of semi-popular magazines and book reviews as well as when testifying as an expert witness in court.
sparring partners have included Allan Bloom, John Finnis and Robert P. George, Harvey Mansfield and Judith Butler, among others.
is Ernst Freund Distinguished Service Professor of Law and Ethics at the University of Chicago Law School.
also holds cross-appointments in the Divinity School and in the Departments of Philosophy and Classics.
previously taught at Harvard University and Brown University where
held the rank of University Professor.
During the 2006-07 academic year
and
partner, Cass Sunstein are visiting professors of law at Harvard, where both have an outstanding offer to join the law school faculty.
